body:
Looks like this is because I cross compile the binaries from linux

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20609415/cross-compiling-user-current-not-implemented-on-linux-amd64

If you have a go installation should should be able to build it yourself fairly easily with `go install github.com/ncw/rclone` and that should work according to the above.

Unfortunately I don't have an OSX machine to test.

I'll see if I can put in a workaround on OSX

Thanks for the bug report

-- Nick

Thanks. Never complied anything like this but will have look. having spent some more time looking because cannot identify Current User it creates the .config file in which ever directory it is run from not a problem just means either adding that directory to the Path or exciting with full path to executable.

I found a library which I could use to fix this problem

https://github.com/mitchellh/go-homedir

Which solves exactly this problem.  I'll have a go at using that.

```
This is a Go library for detecting the user's home directory without the use of cgo, so the library can be used in cross-compilation environments.

Usage is incredibly simple, just call homedir.Dir() to get the home directory for a user, and homedir.Expand() to expand the ~ in a path to the home directory.

Why not just use os/user? The built-in os/user package requires cgo on Darwin systems. This means that any Go code that uses that package cannot cross compile. But 99% of the time the use for os/user is just to retrieve the home directory, which we can do for the current user without cgo. This library does that, enabling cross-compilation.
```

Great had just opened Xcode to try and install go to attempt compiling

> On 11 Dec 2014, at 16:10, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> I found a library which I could use to fix this problem
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/15#issuecomment-66642148.
You could as a workaround use `rclone --config ~/.rclone.conf` and that should give the same effect.

I've just uploaded v1.06 which should fix this problem.  Please re-open this ticket if it doesn't.

Thanks for the bug report

Nick

Thanks helpful.
Out of interest just noticed now gcutils (for G Cloud is GPL a) has been updated and now supports Rsync do you think that it could be used to achieve sync with Google Drive providing a suitable reference to GDrive instead of GC. 

Sent from my iPad

> On 12 Dec 2014, at 20:16, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> I've just uploaded v1.06 which should fix this problem. Please re-open this ticket if it doesn't.
> 
> Thanks for the bug report
> 
> Nick
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

No I do't think that would work.  The Google cloud storage is a very simple objects in a bucket system.  Whereas Google Drive is much more like a file system with directories and files - conceptually quite different.

Thanks - I had the impression from my reading that the the rsync command would sync the tree within the bucket in the same way that that GDrive or one of its sub directories act as an equivalent "bucket"

Cheers

Sent from my iPad

> On 13 Dec 2014, at 10:15, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> No I do't think that would work. The Google cloud storage is a very simple objects in a bucket system. Whereas Google Drive is much more like a file system with directories and files - conceptually quite different.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

issue.title: Darwin AMD64 Cross Compiled Binary Issue

repository.name: pact
repository.description: An experimental cryptographic application for encrypting and decrypting data which implements the experimental cryptographic library MSG.

issue.body:
Need repro to determine if it's the actual compilation, a non-cross platform friendly piece of code, or a makefile packaging error.

Known:
- Windows binary tested on a VM confirmed working.

issue.title: Try using home-dir if os/user fails (mac os)

repository.name: go-bootstrap
repository.description: Generates a lean and mean Go web project.

issue.title: switch user.current -> homedir.dir

repository.name: softlayer-go
repository.description: SoftLayer API Client for the Go Language

issue.body: The call `user.Current` depends on cgo to compile but when you cross compile on OSX this is not available.  Per this [github issue](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/15) there is a library that can get the home dir without using cgo.  The library is https://github.com/mitchellh/go-homedir and its licensed under MIT.
